questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing lower back and neck pain for the past 7 months. The pain is worse in the morning and improves when he plays basketball. He has noticed shortness of breath while playing for the past 2 months. He is sexually active with two female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. He appears lethargic. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the back shows tenderness over the sacroiliac joints. Range of motion is limited by pain. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Chest expansion is decreased on full inspiration. His leukocyte count is 14,000/mm3 and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 84 mm/h. An x-ray of the spine shows erosion and sclerosis of the sacroiliac joints and loss of spinal lordosis. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Paresthesia over the anterolateral part of the thigh
Hyperextension of the proximal interphalangeal joints with flexion of the distal interphalangeal joints
Nail pitting and separation of the nail from the nailbed
Tenderness at the Achilles tendon insertion site
Ulnar deviation of the fingers bilaterally
Scaly, plaque-like lesions on the dorsal side of the elbows
Erythema and inflammation of the conjunctiva

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Paresthesia and pain over the anterolateral part of the thigh is a common finding in individuals with spinal disk herniation at the L2–L3 level. While herniated disks can present with decreased range of motion of the spine, individuals typically have spinal tenderness at the affected site, in this case over the L2–L3 spinous processes. Additionally, individuals with L2–L3 disk herniation have weakness of their quadriceps and a diminished knee reflex. Spinal disk herniation does not cause reduced chest expansion, leukocytosis, or a raised ESR. Lastly, x-ray findings of disk herniation show decreased disk height without involvement of the sacroiliac joint.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperextension of the proximal interphalangeal joints with flexion of the distal interphalangeal joints is the swan neck deformity commonly seen in chronic established rheumatoid arthritis (RA). RA can also cause joint stiffness that improves with activity and lung disease. However, it more commonly affects middle-aged women and involves the peripheral small and large joints and the cervical spine, with very infrequent involvement of the thoracolumbar spine and sacroiliac joints.
Image Description:

Proximal interphalangeal joint hyperextension and distal interphalangeal joint flexion

C) INCORRECT:

Onycholysis (separation of the nail from the nail bed) and nail pitting commonly occur in individuals with psoriatic arthritis. Although a subtype of psoriatic arthritis can affect the spine, causing sacroiliitis and spondylitis, individuals are more likely to have dactylitis. Additionally, individuals typically have skin lesions typical of psoriasis. Lastly, the radiologic features of psoriatic arthritis commonly involve unilateral sacroiliitis with erosion and new bone formation, which is not seen on this patient's x-ray.

D) CORRECT:

Tenderness at the Achilles tendon insertion site indicates heel enthesitis, which is a common finding in individuals with AS. About half of the patients with AS will have enthesitis at some point in the course of the disease. Enthesitis is generally a clinical diagnosis, but ultrasonography can also be used for the detection and assessment of the condition.

Individuals with AS commonly develop restrictive pulmonary disease as a result of the decreased mobility of their spine and thorax. This is likely the cause of this patient's shortness of breath and decreased chest expansion on inspiration.

E) INCORRECT:

Bilateral ulnar deviation of the fingers is commonly seen in chronic established rheumatoid arthritis (RA). While RA can also cause joint stiffness that improves with activity and lung disease, it commonly affects middle-aged women and involves the peripheral joints and the cervical spine, with very infrequent involvement of the thoracolumbar spine and sacroiliac joints.

F) INCORRECT:

Scaly, plaque-like lesions on the dorsal side of the elbows occur in individuals with psoriasis, which is associated with psoriatic arthritis in about half of cases. Psoriatic arthritis commonly causes dactylitis, but a subtype can cause sacroiliitis and spondylitis. The radiologic features of psoriatic arthritis commonly include unilateral sacroiliitis with erosion and new bone formation, which are not seen on this patient's x-ray.
Image Description:

Multiple sharply demarcated erythematosquamous plaques with coarse, silver-white scaling are visible on the extensor sides of the lower arms and elbows.

G) INCORRECT:

Erythema and inflammation of the conjunctiva (conjunctivitis) are seen in reactive arthritis. While this patient's sexual history puts him at risk for reactive arthritis and individuals with reactive arthritis can present with lower back pain and sacroiliitis, asymmetrical oligoarthritis of the lower extremities is more typical. Additionally, this man does not have a history of a preceding bacterial infection of the gastrointestinal or genitourinary tract or other features of reactive arthritis, e.g., a lesion on the glans penis (balanitis circinata) or hyperkeratinization of the palms and soles (keratoma blenorrhagicum).
questions.hint: Back pain that is worse in the morning and improves with physical activity, in combination with leukocytosis, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), and characteristic x-ray findings (erosion and sclerosis of the sacroiliac joints, loss of spinal lordosis), suggests ankylosing spondylitis (AS).

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to her physician because of increasing back pain for the past 10 months. The pain is worse in the morning when she wakes up and improves with activity. She used to practice yoga, but stopped 5 months ago as bending forward became increasingly difficult. She has also had bilateral hip pain for the past 4 months. She has not had any change in urination. She has celiac disease and eats a gluten-free diet. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 116/72 mmHg. Examination shows the range of spinal flexion is limited. Flexion, abduction, and external rotation of bilateral hips produces pain. An x-ray of her pelvis is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Presence of anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although rheumatoid factor is a nonspecific finding that can be found in many conditions, it is classically associated with rheumatoid arthritis (RA). While women of childbearing age are at higher risk for RA, it rarely affects the thoracic or lumbar spine. Instead, RA typically causes symmetric polyarthritis (usually the proximal interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints of the hands).

B) CORRECT:

More than 90% of patients with AS are HLA-B27 positive. HLA-B27 testing is indicated to diagnose AS in patients with inconclusive findings on physical examination and/or pelvic x-ray. Although most patients with AS are HLA-B27 positive, less than 5% of people who are HLA-B27 positive develop the disease. Isolated HLA-B27 positivity has little clinical significance. Gene positivity only supports the diagnosis in patients with clinical suspicion of an associated disease (e.g., chronic low back pain and morning stiffness).

C) INCORRECT:

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are diagnostic of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). This patient is at increased risk of SLE (woman of childbearing age, history of celiac disease – an autoimmune disease). Although SLE often causes joint pain, this woman has no other evidence of the disease (e.g., malar rash, photosensitivity). Additionally, SLE typically causes nonerosive arthritis which appears normal on x-ray. This patient's x-ray shows joint abnormalities.

D) INCORRECT:

Creatine phosphokinase is elevated following muscle damage (e.g., vigorous exercise, myositis, rhabdomyolysis). Although lumbar muscle damage is a common cause of acute low back pain, it would not persist for 9 months. Additionally, muscle damage would not explain this patient's x-ray abnormalities.

E) INCORRECT:

The presence of both anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies is suggestive of either Sjogren syndrome or systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), for which this patient is at increased risk (woman of childbearing age, history of autoimmune disease). While both Sjogren syndrome and SLE frequently cause joint pain, this patient lacks associated symptoms (e.g., dry eye/mouth for Sjogren syndrome or rash for SLE). In addition, neither of these diseases cause joint abnormalities on x-ray.

F) INCORRECT:

HLA-DR3 is associated with a number of autoimmune diseases, including systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). This patient is at elevated risk of SLE (woman of childbearing age, history of celiac disease – an autoimmune disease). Although SLE often causes joint pain, this woman has no other evidence of the disease (e.g., malar rash, photosensitivity). Also, SLE typically causes nonerosive arthritis which appears normal on x-ray; this patient's x-ray shows joint abnormalities.
questions.hint: This patient's history of progressively worsening back pain that improves with activity, impaired spinal flexion, and bilateral hip pain combined with the radiologic findings of sacroiliitis are consistent with ankylosing spondylitis (AS).

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man comes to his physician because he has started to experience shortness of breath with exertion. He does not have shortness of breath at rest. He has also had lower back pain for the past year. He describes the pain as an aching stiffness that improves with movement. He has not had fever, cough, rhinorrhea, or weight loss. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable and he takes no routine medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows tenderness over the sacroiliac joints bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. X-rays of the spine and pelvis show bilateral sacroiliac joint erosions and spinal syndesmophytes. This patient is most likely to develop which of the following sets of findings on pulmonary function testing?



Lung compliance
FEV1

FVC
Residual volume (RV)
DLCO




A
Increased
decreased
decreased
increased
decreased


B
Normal
decreased
decreased
increased
normal


C
Normal
decreased
decreased
normal
normal


D
Decreased
normal
decreased
decreased
increased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Features of obstructive lung disease (decreased FEV1, decreased FVC, increased RV) combined with increased lung compliance and decreased DLCO are seen in patients with severe emphysema. Ankylosing spondylitis is associated with restrictive lung disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Features of obstructive lung disease (decreased FEV1, decreased FVC, increased RV) combined with normal lung compliance and normal DLCO are seen in patients with chronic bronchitis. Ankylosing spondylitis is associated with restrictive lung disease.

C) CORRECT:

Individuals with ankylosing spondylitis often develop restrictive lung disease either secondary to decreased mobility of the thoracic spine and costovertebral joints or interstitial lung disease. Restrictive lung disease manifests with normal or decreased FEV1 and decreased FVC. Patients with disease secondary to extrapulmonary conditions present with normal lung compliance (no changes in the elastic properties of lung tissue or in surface tension), normal residual volume (no changes in lung parenchyma), and normal DLCO (no change in alveolar surface area). Patients with disease due to parenchymal conditions present with decreased lung compliance (fibrotic lung parenchyma compromises the lung's ability to distend), decreased residual volume (enhanced elastic recoil decreases pulmonary volumes) and decreased DLCO (alveolar-capillary membrane thickens and compromises diffusion).

D) INCORRECT:

Normal FEV1 with decreased FVC, decreased RV, and decreased lung compliance is typically seen in patients with restrictive lung disease due to an intraparenchymal pathology (e.g., interstitial lung disease). Although restrictive lung disease secondary to interstitial disease can be seen in ankylosing spondylitis, patients with interstitial lung disease have a decreased rather than increased DLCO..
questions.hint: This young man presents with progressive shortness of breath, lower back pain that improves with movement, and x-ray findings of sacroiliac joint erosions and spinal syndesmophytes, which suggests ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man comes to the physician 1 hour after he slipped in the shower and fell on his back. Since the event, he has had severe neck pain. He rates the pain as an 8–9 out of 10. On questioning, he has had lower back pain for the past 2 years that radiates to the buttocks bilaterally. He reports that the pain sometimes awakens him at night and that it is worse in the morning or when he has been resting for a while. His back is very stiff in the morning and he is able to move normally only after taking a hot shower. His temperature is 36.3°C (97.3°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 145/98 mm Hg. Range of motion of the neck is limited due to pain; the lumbar spine has a decreased range of motion. There is tenderness over the sacroiliac joints. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the cervical spine shows decreased bone density of the vertebrae. An MRI shows a C2 vertebral fracture as well as erosions and sclerosis of the sacroiliac joints bilaterally. The patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following findings?

choices.text: Foot drop and difficulty heel walking
Stiffness and deformity of the fingers and hands

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Foot drop and difficulty heel walking would signify weakness of the dorsiflexors in the foot, which may be a finding associated with lumbar disk herniation in the most common location, the L5–S1 disk (S1 nerve root compression). Although it is a common cause of lower back pain that radiates to the buttocks, lumbar disk herniation would cause sciatica and a positive straight leg raise test, not the chronic inflammatory-type pain (morning stiffness and worsening with rest) seen in this patient. Also, MRI would demonstrate disk herniation rather than bilateral sacroiliitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Urinary and fecal incontinence may be a focal neurological deficit associated with conus medullaris syndrome or cauda equina syndrome. While these may cause lower back pain, symptom onset would be acute and rapidly progressive, as opposed to the 2-year history of chronic inflammatory-type pain seen in this patient. Also, MRI would demonstrate compression of the conus medullaris or cauda equina rather than bilateral sacroiliitis.

C) INCORRECT:

A recent episode of urethritis would be a finding associated with reactive arthritis. While it is among the seronegative spondyloarthropathies that can cause inflammatory-type joint pain, reactive arthritis classically presents as an asymmetric migratory arthritis of the lower extremities, with new joints involved sequentially over days, rather than predominantly lumbar spine pain. While reactive arthritis may cause unilateral sacroiliitis, bilateral sacroiliitis on MRI is a finding more suggestive of AS.

D) INCORRECT:

Stiffness and deformity of the fingers and hands, specifically swelling of the proximal interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints, Boutonniere deformities, and swan neck deformities, are associated with rheumatoid arthritis. Although RA may cause chronic inflammatory-type joint pain, the most commonly involved joints are the small joints of the hands, wrists, knees, and ankles, or rarely the cervical spine; RA normally spares the thoracic and lumbar spine. Also, MRI would show bony erosion and joint space narrowing rather than bilateral sacroiliitis.
Image Description:

Female patient with rheumatoid arthitis

Swelling is seen especially of the proximal interphalangeal joints.

E) INCORRECT:

Back swelling and erythema may be findings associated with an infection that, by contiguous or hematogenous spread, can be the source of vertebral osteomyelitis. Although it can be a cause of back pain that is worse at night and not relieved by rest, vertebral osteomyelitis would classically present with focal pain over the spinous process of the involved vertebra and possibly systemic symptoms of infection, including fever. Moreover, this patient has no obvious risk factors for osteomyelitis, such as history of sepsis, open fractures, diabetes mellitus, or IV drug use. Finally, MRI is the most sensitive diagnostic study for osteomyelitis and would not have findings limited to bilateral sacroiliitis.
Image Description:

X-ray lumbar spine (lateral view)

The inferior endplate of L2 and superior endplate of L3 are osteopenic and the cortices appear fragmented (green ellipse). The intervening L2–3 disc space is narrowed.

F) CORRECT:

Ankylosing spondylitis is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy and is associated with extraarticular manifestations, the most common of which is acute unilateral anterior uveitis (∼ 25% of cases). Further findings in this patient would, therefore, most likely include eye redness and pain. Other associated, though rarer, extraarticular findings of ankylosing spondylitis include gastrointestinal (inflammatory bowel disease), cardiac (aortic insufficiency, AV block), and renal (IgA nephropathy).

G) INCORRECT:

Constipation and muscle weakness may be symptoms of hypercalcemia, a finding associated with multiple myeloma. Although it may be a cause of back pain and pathological fractures of the spine, multiple myeloma classically presents in older individuals with evidence of lytic “punched-out” lesions on imaging. Multiple myeloma is unlikely in this 33-year-old man with bilateral sacroiliitis on MRI.
questions.hint: This young man, who presents with a C2 vertebral fracture following a fall, has a 2-year history of lower back pain of the inflammatory type (indicated by morning stiffness and worsening with rest), limited range of motion of the lumbar spine, and evidence of sacroiliitis on MRI. These findings suggest ankylosing spondylitis (AS), which may lead to osteoporosis and an increased risk of pathological fractures.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing back pain for the past 6 months. The pain is worse when he wakes up and improves throughout the day. He has difficulty bending forward. He has taken ibuprofen and celecoxib for the past 3 months, which provided limited relief. His only current medication is a topical corticosteroid for an itchy skin condition. His mother has rheumatoid arthritis. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 126/82 mm Hg. Examination shows a limited spinal flexion. He has two patches with erythematous papules on his right forearm. There is tenderness on percussion of the sacroiliac joints. An x-ray of the patient's spine is shown. Which of the following is most likely to improve this patient's mobility?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although treatment with DMARDs such as leflunomide may be beneficial for patients with AS, especially when accompanied by peripheral arthritis, it is not a common treatment option to improve mobility. Moreover, among the DMARDs used in the treatment of AS, sulfasalazine is preferred over leflunomide.

Leflunomide is used as first-line treatment of nonsevere psoriatic arthritis. Psoriatic arthritis may also manifest at this age with spinal joint pain (in up to 40% of cases) and ankylosis on x-ray that may cause restricted movement. However, this man lacks other important findings of psoriatic arthritis, such as arthritis of the phalangeal joints or nail changes (pitting, onycholysis).

B) CORRECT:

Additional treatment with a TNF-α inhibitor, such as etanercept, is indicated for improving spine mobility and reducing pain in patients with AS who have persistent symptoms despite NSAID use, which is the first-line treatment for ankylosing spondylitis, for > 2 months. Some studies suggest that these agents may also slow down radiographic disease progression after several years of treatment. In addition, every patient should receive regular physical therapy to maintain range of motion and posture. However, there is no curative treatment for AS.

C) INCORRECT:

Although treatment with DMARDs such as methotrexate (MTX) may be beneficial for patients with AS, especially when accompanied by peripheral arthritis, it is not a common treatment option to improve mobility. Moreover, among the DMARDs used in the treatment of AS, sulfasalazine is preferred over MTX.

MTX is used as first-line treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and psoriatic arthritis. RA of the spine can also result in back pain that improves throughout the day and is commonly associated with a positive family history. As for psoriatic arthritis, patients may also present at this age with spinal joint pain (in up to 40% of cases) and ankylosis on x-ray that may cause restricted movement. However, this man lacks other important findings of both conditions, such as arthritis of the phalangeal joints.

D) INCORRECT:

Wedge osteotomy is a surgical treatment option that may be performed in patients with AS who present with severe impairment of spine flexion causing an inability to look forward. To improve mobility in this patient, adjunct medical treatment should be tried prior to surgical treatment options.

E) INCORRECT:

Some studies suggest that systemic treatment with prednisolone may result in short-term symptom relief in patients with AS. Similarly to systemic therapy, intra-articular treatment with glucocorticoids, such as methylprednisolone (not prednisolone), can provide temporary relief in patients with severe disease. However, glucocorticoids are not routinely used for long-term therapy, as they can further decrease the bone density that is already lowered in most patients with AS.

F) INCORRECT:

Although some studies suggest that targeting therapy with rituximab may also cause remission in patients with AS, there is currently insufficient data that proves its efficacy. Rituximab is used in the treatment of various other autoimmune diseases including some cases of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). RA of the spine can also result in back pain that improves throughout the day and is commonly associated with a positive family history. However, this patient lacks other important features of the disease, such as arthritis of the phalangeal joints.
questions.hint: A man in his thirties with increasing back pain (worse in the morning, improves with activity), limited spine mobility, a positive Mennell sign (percussion of sacroiliac joints elicits pain), and syndesmophytes on spinal x-ray (bamboo spine) is highly suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis (AS). The two itchy patches are most likely eczema unrelated to his chief complaint.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male comes to the physician for worsening back pain. The pain began 10 months ago, is worse in the morning, and improves with activity. He has also had bilateral hip pain and difficulty bending forward during exercise for the past 3 months. He has celiac disease and eats a gluten-free diet. Examination shows a limited range of spinal flexion. Flexion, abduction, and external rotation of both hips produces pain. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following laboratory findings?

choices.text: Presence of anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Creatine phosphokinase is elevated following brain or muscle damage (e.g., vigorous exercise, myositis, rhabdomyolysis). Lumbar muscle damage is a common cause of acute lower back pain, but unlike our patient, symptoms usually worsen with muscle use, and pain resolves within 2 months for 90% of patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are diagnostic of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Although this patient 's history of celiac disease (an autoimmune disease) and joint pain are associated with SLE, he has no other evidence of the disease (e.g., malar rash, photosensitivity).

C) INCORRECT:

The presence of both anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies is suggestive of either Sjogren's syndrome or systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), for which this patient is at increased risk (history of Celiac disease). While both diseases frequently cause joint pain, this patient lacks associated symptoms (e.g., dry eye/mouth for Sjogren's syndrome or rash for SLE).

D) INCORRECT:

Although rheumatoid factor is a nonspecific finding, it is classically associated with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and absent in seronegative spondyloarthropathies. Unlike this patient, RA typically causes a symmetric polyarthritis (usually the PIP and MCP joints of the hands) in women of childbearing age and rarely affects the thoracic or lumbar spine.

E) CORRECT:

90–95% of patients with ankylosing spondylitis are HLA-B27 positive, compared to 6% of the general population. HLA-B27 testing is indicated to diagnose ankylosing spondylitis in patients with an inconclusive clinical presentation and pelvic x-ray.

Although most patients with ankylosing spondylitis are HLA-B27 positive, fewer than 5% of people who are HLA-B27 positive develop the disease. Isolated HLA-B27 positivity has little clinical significance. Gene positivity only supports the diagnosis in patients with clinical suspicion of an associated disease (e.g., chronic lower back pain and morning stiffness).

F) INCORRECT:

HLA-DR3 is positive in some autoimmune diseases, including systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Although this patient 's history of celiac disease (an autoimmune disease) and joint pain are associated with SLE, this patient has no other evidence of the disease (e.g., malar rash, photosensitivity).
questions.hint: This patient's history of progressively worsening back pain that is worse in the morning, impaired spinal flexion, and bilateral hip pain are consistent with ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up evaluation for chronic lower back pain. He has back stiffness that lasts all morning and slowly improves throughout the day. He has tried multiple over-the-counter medications, including ibuprofen, without any improvement in his symptoms. Physical examination shows tenderness over the iliac crest bilaterally and limited range of motion of the lumbar spine with forward flexion. The results of HLA-B27 testing are positive. An x-ray of the lumbar spine shows fusion of the lumbar vertebrae and sacroiliac joints. The physician plans to prescribe a new medication but first orders a tuberculin skin test to assess for the risk of latent tuberculosis reactivation. Inhibition of which of the following is the most likely primary mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase (IMPDH) controls the synthesis of purine nucleotides, which are needed for cellular proliferation. IMPDH inhibitors, such as mycophenolate mofetil and ribavirin, inhibit lymphocyte proliferation and are used as immunosuppressants (e.g., to prevent organ rejection after transplantation). They are not routinely used in the management of ankylosing spondylitis. An active systemic infection, including tuberculosis, is a contraindication to IMPDH inhibitor use. Tuberculin testing is used to detect latent tuberculosis and is not routinely indicated before initiating treatment with IMPDH inhibitors.
Image Description:

Mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) acts by inhibiting inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase (IMPDH), resulting in selective inhibition of lymphocyte proliferation.

Azathioprine (AZA) is a purine analog that is converted, first, to 6-mercaptopurine and, then, into thioinosine monophosphate (TIM), a cytotoxic agent, which acts to block nucleotide synthesis and inhibit lymphocyte proliferation.

Methotrexate (MTX) is a folic acid antagonist (antimetabolite), which acts primarily by inhibiting the clonal expansion of B and T cells.

Cyclophosphamide causes alkylation of DNA/RNA, resulting in impaired DNA cross-linking and DNA synthesis.

Basiliximab/daclizumab inhibits the alpha chain (CD25 antigen) of the IL-2 receptor of T cells, resulting in a reduction of T-cell responses and the expansion of natural killer cells.

Sirolimus/everolimus inhibits mTOR kinase resulting in the inhibition of the IL-2-mediated cell cycle. This leads to reduced T-cell activation and B-cell differentiation, resulting in decreased IgM, IgG, and IgA production.

Tacrolimus (FK 506) and pimecrolimus bind to the FK506 binding protein (FKBP) resulting in inhibition of calcineurin, an enzyme necessary for the activation of NFAT. This leads to reduced gene transcription and activation of T cells. Cyclosporine A binds cyclophilin, which also inhibits calcineurin.

Glucocorticoids (corticosteroids) directly inhibit intracellular NF-κB, a protein complex responsible for transcription of DNA, cytokine production, and cell survival.

B) CORRECT:

TNF-α is a cytokine that upregulates inflammation in numerous conditions, including ankylosing spondylitis (AS). TNF-α inhibitors can improve spine mobility and reduce pain in patients with AS. However, the pro-inflammatory action of TNF-α also plays a key role in granuloma formation and containment of tuberculosis. Inhibition of TNF-α could disrupt the granulomas, thereby releasing intracellular mycobacteria and reactivating latent tuberculosis. Thus, TNF-α inhibitors are contraindicated in individuals with latent tuberculosis, necessitating routine screening tests before initiation of treatment in all individuals.

C) INCORRECT:

Nuclear factor κB (NF-κB), which promotes pro-inflammatory cytokine COX-2 production, is inhibited by glucocorticoids. While temporary intra-articular glucocorticoids may be used in severe cases of ankylosing spondylitis (AS), this does not reactivate latent tuberculosis. In contrast, chronic use of systemic glucocorticoids can reactivate latent tuberculosis and would justify tuberculin skin testing. However, long-term high-dose steroids are not recommended in AS cases.
Image Description:

Mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) acts by inhibiting inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase (IMPDH), resulting in selective inhibition of lymphocyte proliferation.

Azathioprine (AZA) is a purine analog that is converted, first, to 6-mercaptopurine and, then, into thioinosine monophosphate (TIM), a cytotoxic agent, which acts to block nucleotide synthesis and inhibit lymphocyte proliferation.

Methotrexate (MTX) is a folic acid antagonist (antimetabolite), which acts primarily by inhibiting the clonal expansion of B and T cells.

Cyclophosphamide causes alkylation of DNA/RNA, resulting in impaired DNA cross-linking and DNA synthesis.

Basiliximab/daclizumab inhibits the alpha chain (CD25 antigen) of the IL-2 receptor of T cells, resulting in a reduction of T-cell responses and the expansion of natural killer cells.

Sirolimus/everolimus inhibits mTOR kinase resulting in the inhibition of the IL-2-mediated cell cycle. This leads to reduced T-cell activation and B-cell differentiation, resulting in decreased IgM, IgG, and IgA production.

Tacrolimus (FK 506) and pimecrolimus bind to the FK506 binding protein (FKBP) resulting in inhibition of calcineurin, an enzyme necessary for the activation of NFAT. This leads to reduced gene transcription and activation of T cells. Cyclosporine A binds cyclophilin, which also inhibits calcineurin.

Glucocorticoids (corticosteroids) directly inhibit intracellular NF-κB, a protein complex responsible for transcription of DNA, cytokine production, and cell survival.

D) INCORRECT:

Calcineurin is a protein phosphatase enzyme involved in IL-2 dependent T-cell activation and proliferation. Calcineurin inhibitors, such as tacrolimus and cyclosporine, are potent immunosuppressants. While long-term use of calcineurin inhibitors may increase the risk of infection, they are not associated with reactivation of latent tuberculosis. In addition, these drugs are not used in the management of ankylosing spondylitis.
Image Description:

Mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) acts by inhibiting inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase (IMPDH), resulting in selective inhibition of lymphocyte proliferation.

Azathioprine (AZA) is a purine analog that is converted, first, to 6-mercaptopurine and, then, into thioinosine monophosphate (TIM), a cytotoxic agent, which acts to block nucleotide synthesis and inhibit lymphocyte proliferation.

Methotrexate (MTX) is a folic acid antagonist (antimetabolite), which acts primarily by inhibiting the clonal expansion of B and T cells.

Cyclophosphamide causes alkylation of DNA/RNA, resulting in impaired DNA cross-linking and DNA synthesis.

Basiliximab/daclizumab inhibits the alpha chain (CD25 antigen) of the IL-2 receptor of T cells, resulting in a reduction of T-cell responses and the expansion of natural killer cells.

Sirolimus/everolimus inhibits mTOR kinase resulting in the inhibition of the IL-2-mediated cell cycle. This leads to reduced T-cell activation and B-cell differentiation, resulting in decreased IgM, IgG, and IgA production.

Tacrolimus (FK 506) and pimecrolimus bind to the FK506 binding protein (FKBP) resulting in inhibition of calcineurin, an enzyme necessary for the activation of NFAT. This leads to reduced gene transcription and activation of T cells. Cyclosporine A binds cyclophilin, which also inhibits calcineurin.

Glucocorticoids (corticosteroids) directly inhibit intracellular NF-κB, a protein complex responsible for transcription of DNA, cytokine production, and cell survival.

E) INCORRECT:

mTOR kinase promotes cellular proliferation and differentiation. Inhibitors of mTOR kinase (e.g., sirolimus and everolimus) inhibit lymphocyte proliferation and differentiation, resulting in decreased immunoglobulin synthesis, and are used as antineoplastic and immunosuppressant drugs. As these drugs can cause leukopenia, individuals treated with mTOR kinase inhibitors are at an increased risk of infection; however, reactivation of latent tuberculosis is not seen. In addition, mTOR kinase inhibitors are not routinely used in the management of ankylosing spondylitis.
Image Description:

Mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) acts by inhibiting inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase (IMPDH), resulting in selective inhibition of lymphocyte proliferation.

Azathioprine (AZA) is a purine analog that is converted, first, to 6-mercaptopurine and, then, into thioinosine monophosphate (TIM), a cytotoxic agent, which acts to block nucleotide synthesis and inhibit lymphocyte proliferation.

Methotrexate (MTX) is a folic acid antagonist (antimetabolite), which acts primarily by inhibiting the clonal expansion of B and T cells.

Cyclophosphamide causes alkylation of DNA/RNA, resulting in impaired DNA cross-linking and DNA synthesis.

Basiliximab/daclizumab inhibits the alpha chain (CD25 antigen) of the IL-2 receptor of T cells, resulting in a reduction of T-cell responses and the expansion of natural killer cells.

Sirolimus/everolimus inhibits mTOR kinase resulting in the inhibition of the IL-2-mediated cell cycle. This leads to reduced T-cell activation and B-cell differentiation, resulting in decreased IgM, IgG, and IgA production.

Tacrolimus (FK 506) and pimecrolimus bind to the FK506 binding protein (FKBP) resulting in inhibition of calcineurin, an enzyme necessary for the activation of NFAT. This leads to reduced gene transcription and activation of T cells. Cyclosporine A binds cyclophilin, which also inhibits calcineurin.

Glucocorticoids (corticosteroids) directly inhibit intracellular NF-κB, a protein complex responsible for transcription of DNA, cytokine production, and cell survival.
questions.hint: This young man presents with findings suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis (chronic lower back pain with morning stiffness, tenderness over sacroiliac joint indicating sacroiliitis, decreased spine mobility, and positive HLA-B27 test), which is confirmed by x-ray showing fusion of adjacent vertebrae (“bamboo spine”). The first choice medication (NSAID) did not prove effective here. Second-line drugs may cause reactivation of latent tuberculosis by disrupting granuloma stabilization.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening lower back stiffness for the past year. The stiffness improves with movement. He has also experienced shortness of breath while exercising. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Examination shows tenderness over the sacroiliac joints bilaterally. All lung fields are clear to auscultation. A chest x-ray shows synostoses and narrowing of the costovertebral and costosternal joint spaces and no other abnormalities. Pulmonary function testing is most likely to disclose which of the following sets of findings?



Lung compliance
FEV1

Forced vital capacity (FVC)



A
Decreased
decreased
decreased


B
Increased
decreased
decreased


C
Normal
decreased
decreased


D
Normal
increased
normal


E
Normal
decreased
normal
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased lung compliance with decreased FEV1 and decreased FVC is typically seen in patients with restrictive lung disease due to an intraparenchymal pathology such as pulmonary fibrosis. The lung parenchyma itself is typically unaffected in ankylosing spondylitis and lung compliance usually remains normal. Apical pulmonary fibrosis only rarely occurs in patients with ankylosing spondylitis (< 1% of patients) and this patient has no features on auscultation or chest x-ray to indicate the presence of this complication.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased lung compliance with decreased FEV1 and decreased FVC occurs in patients with severe emphysema. Ankylosing spondylitis would not result in increased lung compliance.

C) CORRECT:

Individuals with ankylosing spondylitis frequently develop some of the classical features of restrictive lung disease (RLD) such as decreased FVC and normal or decreased FEV1. The RLD in ankylosing spondylitis is due to impaired spine and thoracic cage mobility (i.e., an extrinsic cause). The degree of restriction appears to be correlated with the severity of dorsal kyphosis as well as the presence of costovertebral and costosternal ankylosis. Lung compliance and alveolar gas exchange usually remain largely unchanged in extrinsic causes of RLD. In contrast to certain extrinsic causes of RLD (e.g., pleural effusion, obesity), individuals with ankylosing spondylitis can have a normal functional residual capacity and a normal to increased residual volume because the chest wall is at a higher position at rest due to fixation of the rib cage. Only rarely do patients with ankylosing spondylitis develop apical pulmonary fibrosis, an intrinsic cause of RLD.

See “PFT findings in obstructive vs. restrictive lung diseases” table.

D) INCORRECT:

An isolated increase in FEV1 is not associated with any lung pathology. In the setting of diagnostic testing for obstructive lung disease, an increase in FEV1 after bronchodilator reversibility test indicates the patient has a reversible airway obstruction, such as asthma. Ankylosing spondylitis would not result in an isolated increase in FEV1.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased FEV1 with normal lung compliance and normal FVC can be seen in upper airway obstruction and mild obstructive lung disease. Ankylosing spondylitis, on the other hand, would result in restrictive lung disease.
questions.hint: In a young male patient, progressive shortness of breath, tenderness over the sacroiliac joints, and lower back pain that improves with movement indicate ankylosing spondylitis. In this condition, ankylosis of the costosternal and costovertebral joints, dorsal kyphosis, and/or restricted mobility of the thoracic cage and spine lead to restrictive lung disease.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old man reports gradually worsening dyspnea on exertion for 12 months, intermittent chest pain on deep inspiration, and back stiffness for several years. The back stiffness, which has begun to interfere with daily activities, is usually worse in the morning and improves as the day progresses. The patient takes no medications.
His lungs are clear on auscultation. Heart sounds are normal, and there are no murmurs or gallops. The remainder of his examination is unremarkable except for tenderness to palpation over the lumbar spine.
A chest radiograph is normal. Pulmonary function testing reveals the following results:

FEV1 is 76% of predicted.

FVC is 75% of predicted.

FEV1 /FVC ratio is 83%.
Total lung capacity is 74% of predicted.
Functional residual capacity is 82% of predicted.
Residual volume is 79% of predicted.
Diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide is 91% of predicted.

A plain-film radiograph of the lumbar spine is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Begin treatment with a nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug
Order a CT scan of the chest
Prescribe rest and heat for the back pain

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Back pain, morning stiffness, and supportive imaging findings (“bamboo spine” on radiograph) strongly suggest a diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis. Primary pulmonary manifestations include a restrictive process (related to impaired chest-wall expansion from fusion of the costovertebral joints and ankylosis of the thoracic spine) and, less commonly, spontaneous pneumothorax and pulmonary fibrosis.

Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug (NSAID) therapy is an appropriate initial treatment agent. An antitumor necrosis factor drug may be required if the patient does not respond to NSAIDs.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management strategy for newly diagnosed ankylosing spondylitis is initiation of treatment with a nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug.

B) INCORRECT:

Because this patient’s dyspnea on exertion can be explained by the mechanical extrapulmonary restrictive process (supported by pulmonary function test findings of restrictive lung disease but normal diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide), and because the pulmonary examination and the lung fields on chest radiograph are normal, neither bronchoscopy nor chest CT will add useful information.

C) INCORRECT:

Stiffness from ankylosing spondylitis typically improves with activity; thus, advising the patient to rest and avoid activity would not be appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Because this patient’s dyspnea on exertion can be explained by the mechanical extrapulmonary restrictive process (supported by pulmonary function test findings of restrictive lung disease but normal diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide), and because the pulmonary examination and the lung fields on chest radiograph are normal, neither bronchoscopy nor chest CT will add useful information.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with ankylosing spondylitis may develop a dilated aortic root and aortic regurgitation. However, echocardiography is not likely to be helpful in a patient whose cardiac examination and chest radiograph are normal.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old male college student reports low back pain that started about 4 months ago. He has difficulty ambulating because of pain and stiffness, especially in the morning, although the pain improves with movement. He plays intramural sports but does not remember any inciting event. Similar, though less severe, episodes began 2 years earlier, causing him to miss school on several occasions. He takes acetaminophen as needed, but no other medications.
He feels well otherwise and states that he has not experienced fever or weight loss. He has no significant medical history. His father and a paternal uncle developed chronic back problems in their twenties.
His vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows reduced forward and lateral flexion at the lumbar spine, normal range of motion in the cervical spine, and normal chest expansion. Pain is elicited in the lower back bilaterally when you press the anterior superior iliac spine and opposite knee posteriorly while the leg is in flexion, abduction, and external rotation. Other joint findings are unremarkable. Testicles are normal, and there is no evidence of lymphadenopathy.
Basic biochemical laboratory testing is unremarkable. The C-reactive protein level is 1.2 mg/liter (reference range, 0.08–3.10).
Plain radiographs of the sacroiliac joints do not reveal any abnormalities. MRI of the sacroiliac joints identifies subchondral bone-marrow edema and no evidence of bone erosions.
Which one of the following medications is most appropriate for initial management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tumor necrosis factor inhibitors such as etanercept are recommended if NSAIDs do not provide sufficient symptom relief; they are not typically considered first-line treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate has no role in treating axial features of spondyloarthritis. It may be beneficial for patients who have peripheral (nonaxial) manifestations of spondyloarthritis.

C) INCORRECT:

There is no role for scheduled opioid-based therapy for a patient with inflammatory back pain. Treatment should be aimed at alleviating the chronic inflammatory disease, not just masking the symptoms.

D) CORRECT:

Axial spondyloarthritis (SPA) is a chronic systemic inflammatory disease characterized by inflammation of the spine and sacroiliac joints. Affected patients can also experience peripheral inflammatory arthritis, dactylitis, enthesitis, and extraarticular disease (e.g., uveitis). A subset of patients with axial SPA are categorized as having ankylosing spondylitis (AS), in which there is primarily spine involvement, with structural changes that can lead to ankylosis of involved joints.

Axial SPA is more common in men than in women. It tends to appear early in adulthood and is associated with significant morning stiffness and back pain that improves with movement or exercise. Serologic and imaging studies can identify inflammation and sometimes structural changes of AS. The term “nonradiographic axial spondyloarthritis” refers to patients with axial SPA who lack radiographic changes of AS on plain film radiography. In these cases, MRI can often identify inflammation of the axial spine. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein level may or may not be normal in these patients.

Diagnosing axial SPA can be challenging, given the high prevalence of low back pain and the nonspecific nature of laboratory testing. Pain with the FABER test (flexion, abduction, and external rotation of the affected limb) in the absence of pain on passive flexion of the hip is suggestive of sacroiliac joint pain but is not specific.

The prevalence of axial SPA varies among different racial/ethnic groups and is higher in populations with higher rates of HLA-B27. For example, in Canada, people from the First Nations have higher rates of HLA-B27 than other people, and they also have a 3-fold higher prevalence of AS. In the United States, the prevalence of HLA-B27 is 7.5% in non-Hispanic white Americans, 4.6% in Mexican Americans, and 1.1% in non-Hispanic Black Americans. Not surprisingly, axial SPA is found more commonly in non-Hispanic white Americans and less commonly in Hispanic and Black Americans. Nevertheless, most patients with HLA-B27 do not develop axial SPA; only about 5% of patients with HLA-B27 are thought to develop axial SPA, and some people without HLA-B27 can still develop axial SPA.

Treating AS

First-line treatment of axial SPA consists of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and physical therapy. NSAIDs are thought to help with pain as well as reduce inflammation in the joints.

Key learning point: The initial treatment for suspected nonradiographic axial spondyloarthritis consists of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug therapy and physical therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

The use of systemic glucocorticoids for axial spondyloarthritis is not supported by clinical trials, and chronic use of systemic glucocorticoids carries a high risk for adverse effects. Glucocorticoid injections to the sacroiliac joints can be used to treat localized inflammation but are insufficient to treat other sites of disease.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man with a 25-year history of chronic low back pain and four episodes of uveitis in the past 20 years is admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with new-onset congestive heart failure. He first noted dyspnea associated with orthopnea and lower-extremity edema 4 months ago, but his symptoms have deteriorated quickly during the past week. His back pain is worse in the mornings, improves with activity, and has led to significantly restricted spinal flexibility.
On examination, his temperature is 37°C, his heart rate is 102 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 105/62 mm Hg, his respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 95% with 6 liters of supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula. His examination is notable for bibasilar crackles, elevated jugular venous pressure, and a diastolic decrescendo murmur over the aortic area that is graded 3 on a scale of 1 to 4. Lumbar spine range of motion and chest expansion cannot be measured in the ICU setting.
A chest radiograph reveals bilateral infiltrates and pleural effusions consistent with pulmonary edema.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of the patient's aortic regurgitation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Other causes of aortic disease include syphilis, tuberculosis, Takayasu arteritis, Turner syndrome, and connective tissue diseases, such as Marfan syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. However, none of those conditions would cause the chronic low back pain described in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

Other causes of aortic disease include syphilis, tuberculosis, Takayasu arteritis, Turner syndrome, and connective tissue diseases, such as Marfan syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. However, none of those conditions would cause the chronic low back pain described in this case.

C) INCORRECT:

Other causes of aortic disease include syphilis, tuberculosis, Takayasu arteritis, Turner syndrome, and connective tissue diseases, such as Marfan syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. However, none of those conditions would cause the chronic low back pain described in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Other causes of aortic disease include syphilis, tuberculosis, Takayasu arteritis, Turner syndrome, and connective tissue diseases, such as Marfan syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. However, none of those conditions would cause the chronic low back pain described in this case. Ocular manifestations of Marfan disease include retinal detachment and ectopia lentis but not recurrent uveitis.

E) CORRECT:

Ankylosing spondylitis is a rare but important cause of aortic root disease. Inflammatory back pain, a cardinal feature of ankylosing spondylitis, is frequently underrecognized and may lead to a delay in diagnosis of years or even decades. On physical examination, patients demonstrate restricted range of motion in the lumbar spine and reduced chest expansion. Other features of ankylosing spondylitis include uveitis, enthesitis, and peripheral arthritis. Aortic regurgitation has been reported in 6% to 10% of patients with ankylosing spondylitis, and ankylosing spondylitis has also been associated with increased risk for coronary artery disease and congestive heart failure. The management of heart failure and indications for valvular or aortic root replacement in patients with ankylosing spondylitis do not differ from those of the general population.

Key learning point: The cardiovascular manifestations of ankylosing spondylitis include aortic root dilatation and coronary artery disease.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man with Crohn disease that is well controlled with sulfasalazine reports a one-year history of pain involving his upper buttock on both sides. The pain is most bothersome in the morning and at night, when it wakes him from sleep. Acetaminophen does not relieve the pain. He cannot tolerate nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs because they exacerbate his Crohn disease. He denies any fevers, chills, or night sweats.
Physical examination is notable for diffuse but mild tenderness on palpation of the lumbar spine from L2 to S1 and greater tenderness lateral to the L5–S1 region. Simultaneous flexion, abduction, and external rotation of either leg, with the foot on the opposite knee while the patient is supine (FABER test), produces pain in the lower back lateral to the spine.
A radiograph of the lumbar spine and sacroiliac joints is obtained (figure).
Laboratory evaluation reveals a hematocrit of 38% (reference range, 41–53).
What is the most sensitive diagnostic test to determine the cause of this patient’s buttock pain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI of the lumbar spine is not the most sensitive test to determine the cause of this patient’s buttock pain because the lumbar spine is less commonly affected in axial spondyloarthritis than the sacroiliac joints.

B) INCORRECT:

HLA-B27 testing could be considered, but it is not the most sensitive test: only about 75% of patients with spondyloarthritis test positive for HLA-B27. This test is also not specific, as positive results are common in people without spondyloarthritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Measurement of C-reactive protein and other inflammatory markers in a patient with an inflammatory disease, such as Crohn disease, lacks specificity to determine the cause of joint pain. In addition, it has inadequate sensitivity in early disease.

D) CORRECT:

Approximately 10% to 15% of patients with inflammatory bowel disease have concurrent axial spondyloarthritis, manifesting as inflammatory back pain due to sacroiliitis. Symptoms include pain at night, morning stiffness, and improvement with exercise or nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). The sacroiliac joints are affected more often than the lumbar spine. Radiographs can show symmetric fusion and erosions of the sacroiliac joints late in the course of the disease but are typically normal early in the disease.

MRI is more sensitive than radiographs or bone scans in early sacroiliitis and can show bone-marrow edema and synovitis even when lumbar spine radiographs are normal, as in this patient. Given its high sensitivity, MRI is widely accepted as the gold standard for detecting sacroiliac joint involvement in spondyloarthropathy. Of note, abnormal MRI findings are not specific for sacroiliitis; thus, the clinician should consider the patient’s clinical history when interpreting such results. CT can be considered in those who cannot tolerate MRI, but it is less sensitive because it cannot show bone-marrow edema, only bone erosion.

Key learning point: The most sensitive diagnostic test for early inflammatory sacroiliitis in a patient with Crohn disease is MRI of the sacroiliac joints.

E) INCORRECT:

A different imaging modality is more sensitive than bone scans in early sacroiliitis and can show bone-marrow edema and synovitis even when lumbar spine radiographs are normal, as in this patient.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man comes to the office 1 hour after he slipped in the shower and fell on his back. On questioning, he has had lower back pain for the past 2 years that radiates to the buttocks bilaterally. He reports that the pain is worse in the morning or when he has been resting for a while and that his back is very stiff in the morning. Range of motion of the neck is limited due to pain; the lumbar spine has a decreased range of motion. There is tenderness over the sacroiliac joints. An MRI shows a C2 vertebral fracture and evidence of sacroillitis bilaterally. The patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following findings?

choices.text: Foot drop and difficulty heel walking
Stiffness and deformity of the fingers and hands

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Foot drop and difficulty heel walking would signify weakness of the dorsiflexors in the foot, which may be a finding associated with lumbar disk herniation in the most common location, the L5–S1 disk (S1 nerve root compression). Although it is a common cause of lower back pain that radiates to the buttocks, lumbar disk herniation would cause sciatica and a positive straight leg raise test, not the chronic inflammatory-type pain (morning stiffness and worsening with rest) seen in this patient. Also, MRI would demonstrate disk herniation rather than bilateral sacroiliitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Urinary and fecal incontinence may be a focal neurological deficit associated with conus medullaris syndrome or cauda equina syndrome. While these may cause lower back pain, symptom onset would be acute and rapidly progressive, as opposed to the 2-year history of chronic inflammatory-type pain seen in this patient. Also, MRI would demonstrate compression of the conus medullaris or cauda equina rather than bilateral sacroiliitis.

C) INCORRECT:

A recent episode of urethritis would be a finding associated with reactive arthritis. While it is among the seronegative spondyloarthropathies that can cause inflammatory-type joint pain, reactive arthritis classically presents as an asymmetric migratory arthritis of the lower extremities, with new joints involved sequentially over days, rather than predominantly lumbar spine pain. While reactive arthritis may cause unilateral sacroiliitis, bilateral sacroiliitis on MRI is a finding more suggestive of AS.

D) INCORRECT:

Stiffness and deformity of the fingers and hands, specifically swelling of the proximal interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints, Boutonniere deformities, and swan neck deformities, are associated with rheumatoid arthritis. Although RA may cause chronic inflammatory-type joint pain, the most commonly involved joints are the small joints of the hands, wrists, knees, and ankles, or rarely the cervical spine; RA normally spares the thoracic and lumbar spine. Also, MRI would show bony erosion and joint space narrowing rather than bilateral sacroiliitis.
Image Description:

Female patient with rheumatoid arthitis

Swelling is seen especially of the proximal interphalangeal joints.

E) CORRECT:

Ankylosing spondylitis is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy and is associated with extraarticular manifestations, the most common of which is acute unilateral anterior uveitis (∼ 25% of cases). Further findings in this patient would, therefore, most likely include eye redness and pain. Other associated, though rarer, extraarticular findings of ankylosing spondylitis include gastrointestinal (inflammatory bowel disease), cardiac (aortic insufficiency, AV block), and renal (IgA nephropathy).
questions.hint: This young man, who presents with a C2 vertebral fracture following a fall, has a 2-year history of lower back pain of the inflammatory type (indicated by morning stiffness and worsening with rest), limited range of motion of the lumbar spine, and evidence of sacroiliitis on MRI. These findings suggest ankylosing spondylitis (AS), which may lead to osteoporosis and an increased risk of pathological fractures.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male comes to the office for worsening back pain. The pain began 10 months ago, is worse in the morning, and improves with activity. He has also had bilateral hip pain and difficulty bending forward during exercise for the past 3 months. He has celiac disease and eats a gluten-free diet. Examination shows a limited range of spinal flexion. Flexion, abduction, and external rotation of both hips produces pain. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following laboratory findings?

choices.text: Presence of anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are diagnostic of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Although this patient 's history of celiac disease (an autoimmune disease) and joint pain are associated with SLE, he has no other evidence of the disease (e.g., malar rash, photosensitivity).

B) INCORRECT:

The presence of both anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies is suggestive of either Sjogren's syndrome or systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), for which this patient is at increased risk (history of Celiac disease). While both diseases frequently cause joint pain, this patient lacks associated symptoms (e.g., dry eye/mouth for Sjogren's syndrome or rash for SLE).

C) INCORRECT:

Although rheumatoid factor is a nonspecific finding, it is classically associated with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and absent in seronegative spondyloarthropathies. Unlike this patient, RA typically causes a symmetric polyarthritis (usually the PIP and MCP joints of the hands) in women of childbearing age and rarely affects the thoracic or lumbar spine.

D) CORRECT:

90–95% of patients with ankylosing spondylitis are HLA-B27 positive, compared to 6% of the general population. HLA-B27 testing is indicated to diagnose ankylosing spondylitis in patients with an inconclusive clinical presentation and pelvic x-ray.

Although most patients with ankylosing spondylitis are HLA-B27 positive, fewer than 5% of people who are HLA-B27 positive develop the disease. Isolated HLA-B27 positivity has little clinical significance. Gene positivity only supports the diagnosis in patients with clinical suspicion of an associated disease (e.g., chronic lower back pain and morning stiffness).

E) INCORRECT:

HLA-DR3 is positive in some autoimmune diseases, including systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Although this patient 's history of celiac disease (an autoimmune disease) and joint pain are associated with SLE, this patient has no other evidence of the disease (e.g., malar rash, photosensitivity).
questions.hint: This patient's history of progressively worsening back pain that is worse in the morning, impaired spinal flexion, and bilateral hip pain are consistent with ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man reports increasing lower back and neck pain for the past 7 months. The pain is worse in the morning and improves when he plays basketball. He has noticed shortness of breath while playing for the past 2 months. Examination of the back shows tenderness over the sacroiliac joints. Range of motion is limited by pain. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Chest expansion is decreased on full inspiration. His leukocyte count is 14,000/mm3 and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 84 mm/h. An x-ray of the spine shows erosion and sclerosis of the sacroiliac joints and loss of spinal lordosis. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Paresthesia over the anterolateral part of the thigh
Hyperextension of the proximal interphalangeal joints with flexion of the distal interphalangeal joints
Nail pitting and separation of the nail from the nailbed
Tenderness at the Achilles tendon insertion site
Erythema and inflammation of the conjunctiva

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Paresthesia and pain over the anterolateral part of the thigh is a common finding in individuals with spinal disk herniation at the L2–L3 level. While herniated disks can present with decreased range of motion of the spine, individuals typically have spinal tenderness at the affected site, in this case over the L2–L3 spinous processes. Additionally, individuals with L2–L3 disk herniation have weakness of their quadriceps and a diminished knee reflex. Spinal disk herniation does not cause reduced chest expansion, leukocytosis, or a raised ESR. Lastly, x-ray findings of disk herniation show decreased disk height without involvement of the sacroiliac joint.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperextension of the proximal interphalangeal joints with flexion of the distal interphalangeal joints is the swan neck deformity commonly seen in chronic established rheumatoid arthritis (RA). RA can also cause joint stiffness that improves with activity and lung disease. However, it more commonly affects middle-aged women and involves the peripheral small and large joints and the cervical spine, with very infrequent involvement of the thoracolumbar spine and sacroiliac joints.
Image Description:

Proximal interphalangeal joint hyperextension and distal interphalangeal joint flexion

C) INCORRECT:

Onycholysis (separation of the nail from the nail bed) and nail pitting commonly occur in individuals with psoriatic arthritis. Although a subtype of psoriatic arthritis can affect the spine, causing sacroiliitis and spondylitis, individuals are more likely to have dactylitis. Additionally, individuals typically have skin lesions typical of psoriasis. Lastly, the radiologic features of psoriatic arthritis commonly involve unilateral sacroiliitis with erosion and new bone formation, which is not seen on this patient's x-ray.

D) CORRECT:

Tenderness at the Achilles tendon insertion site indicates heel enthesitis, which is a common finding in individuals with AS. About half of the patients with AS will have enthesitis at some point in the course of the disease. Enthesitis is generally a clinical diagnosis, but ultrasonography can also be used for the detection and assessment of the condition.

Individuals with AS commonly develop restrictive pulmonary disease as a result of the decreased mobility of their spine and thorax. This is likely the cause of this patient's shortness of breath and decreased chest expansion on inspiration.

E) INCORRECT:

Erythema and inflammation of the conjunctiva (conjunctivitis) are seen in reactive arthritis. While individuals with reactive arthritis can present with lower back pain and sacroiliitis, asymmetrical oligoarthritis of the lower extremities is more typical. Additionally, this man does not have a history of a preceding bacterial infection of the gastrointestinal or genitourinary tract or other features of reactive arthritis, e.g., a lesion on the glans penis (balanitis circinata) or hyperkeratinization of the palms and soles (keratoma blenorrhagicum). This patient most likely has ankylosing spondylitis, which is associated with acute unilateral anterior uveitis (∼ 25% of cases).
questions.hint: Back pain that is worse in the morning and improves with physical activity, in combination with leukocytosis, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), and characteristic x-ray findings (erosion and sclerosis of the sacroiliac joints, loss of spinal lordosis), suggests ankylosing spondylitis (AS).

questions.text:
A 23-year-old man presents with a 10-month history of progressively worsening low back pain and morning stiffness lasting about 90 minutes. The pain improves with exercise but returns after prolonged rest. He also reports intermittent pain near his Achilles tendon insertion and increasing fatigue. He denies any significant trauma or recent infections. Physical examination shows reduced lumbar flexion, tenderness over both sacroiliac joints, and decreased chest expansion (see lab result).


Test
Result
Normal Values


C-reactive peptide
25 mg/L
< 8.2 mg/L


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fibromyalgia is characterized by diffuse musculoskeletal pain and tender points without inflammation. It does not typically present with prolonged morning stiffness, sacroiliac tenderness, or enthesitis. Elevated C-reactive protein and the pattern of pain improvement with exercise suggest an inflammatory condition, not fibromyalgia.

B) CORRECT:

Ankylosing spondylitis is a systemic inflammatory condition primarily affecting the axial skeleton. It manifests with chronic low back pain and prolonged morning stiffness that improves with exercise. Sacroiliac joint involvement is central to the disease. Decreased chest expansion suggests costovertebral joint involvement. Enthesitis, such as pain near the Achilles tendon insertion, supports the diagnosis. Elevated C-reactive protein levels reflect active inflammation.

Key learning point: Ankylosing spondylitis is characterized by inflammatory back pain, prolonged morning stiffness, and sacroiliac joint involvement.

C) INCORRECT:

Degenerative disc disease typically presents with mechanical back pain that worsens with activity and improves with rest, often in older individuals. The patient's age, inflammatory symptoms, and elevated C-reactive protein suggest an inflammatory rather than degenerative process.

D) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis primarily affects the small joints of the hands and feet, with symmetric joint swelling and pain. Although it can affect the cervical spine, it rarely involves the thoracic or lumbar spine or sacroiliac joints. The patient's axial symptoms and enthesitis do not align with rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old man presents with a 9-month history of progressively worsening low back pain and morning stiffness that improves with exercise. He denies any recent trauma or severe illness. Physical examination reveals mild tenderness over the sacroiliac areas and decreased chest expansion.
Laboratory studies show a moderately elevated C-reactive protein level. Which of the following investigations is most appropriate to confirm the suspected diagnosis?

choices.text: CT scan of the sacroiliac joints

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bone scintigraphy detects increased osteoblastic activity but lacks the sensitivity to reliably identify early inflammatory changes in the sacroiliac joints. Its low spatial resolution and nonspecific uptake patterns can lead to false positives. Imaging modalities like MRI provide more precise anatomical and inflammatory assessments for suspected inflammatory spondyloarthropathy.

B) CORRECT:

MRI is the preferred investigation for detecting sacroiliitis in suspected ankylosing spondylitis due to its high sensitivity for early inflammatory changes, such as bone marrow edema, synovitis, and capsulitis. It can identify active inflammation before structural damage is visible on conventional radiographs, aiding in early diagnosis and management. MRI's ability to distinguish between active inflammation and chronic changes is crucial for assessing disease progression.

Key learning point: MRI of the sacroiliac joint is the most appropriate investigation to establish the diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis, as it can detect early inflammatory changes characteristic of the disease.

C) INCORRECT:

HLA-B27 is associated with ankylosing spondylitis, but its presence is not specific, as many healthy individuals also test positive. While up to 90% of patients with ankylosing spondylitis carry HLA-B27, a positive result does not confirm the diagnosis. Imaging studies are preferred for confirming the diagnosis by revealing characteristic joint changes.

D) INCORRECT:

CT scans provide excellent visualization of bony structures and can detect chronic changes like sclerosis or erosions. However, they are less effective in identifying early inflammatory changes, such as bone marrow edema, which are crucial for early diagnosis of sacroiliitis. Additionally, CT involves ionizing radiation, making it less desirable for young patients when non-radiative options like MRI are available.

questions.text: You are seeing a 33-year-old man in your clinic 1 hour after he slipped in the shower and fell on his back. He reports a 2-year history of lower back pain that radiates to both buttocks. The pain and stiffness are worse in the morning or after periods of rest. On examination, neck range of motion is limited due to pain, and lumbar spine range of motion is decreased. There is tenderness over the sacroiliac joints. MRI reveals a C2 vertebral fracture and bilateral sacroiliitis. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which one of the following findings?

choices.text: Foot drop and difficulty heel walking.
Stiffness and deformity of the fingers and hands.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urinary and fecal incontinence may be a focal neurological deficit associated with conus medullaris syndrome or cauda equina syndrome. While these may cause lower back pain, symptom onset would be acute and rapidly progressive, as opposed to the 2-year history of chronic inflammatory-type pain seen in this patient. Also, MRI would demonstrate compression of the conus medullaris or cauda equina rather than bilateral sacroiliitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Foot drop and difficulty heel walking would signify weakness of the dorsiflexors in the foot, which may be a finding associated with lumbar disk herniation in the most common location, the L5–S1 disk (S1 nerve root compression). Although it is a common cause of lower back pain that radiates to the buttocks, lumbar disk herniation would cause sciatica and a positive straight leg raise test, not the chronic inflammatory-type pain (morning stiffness and worsening with rest) seen in this patient. Also, MRI would demonstrate disk herniation rather than bilateral sacroiliitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Stiffness and deformity of the fingers and hands, specifically swelling of the proximal interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints, Boutonniere deformities, and swan neck deformities, are associated with rheumatoid arthritis. Although RA may cause chronic inflammatory-type joint pain, the most commonly involved joints are the small joints of the hands, wrists, knees, and ankles, or rarely the cervical spine; RA normally spares the thoracic and lumbar spine. Also, MRI would show bony erosion and joint space narrowing rather than bilateral sacroiliitis.

D) INCORRECT:

A recent episode of urethritis would be a finding associated with reactive arthritis. While it is among the seronegative spondyloarthropathies that can cause inflammatory-type joint pain, reactive arthritis classically presents as an asymmetric migratory arthritis of the lower extremities, with new joints involved sequentially over days, rather than predominantly lumbar spine pain. While reactive arthritis may cause unilateral sacroiliitis, bilateral sacroiliitis on MRI is a finding more suggestive of AS.

E) CORRECT:

Ankylosing spondylitis is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy and is associated with extraarticular manifestations, the most common of which is acute unilateral anterior uveitis (∼ 25% of cases). Further findings in this patient would, therefore, most likely include eye redness and pain. Other associated, though rarer, extraarticular findings of ankylosing spondylitis include gastrointestinal (inflammatory bowel disease), cardiac (aortic insufficiency, AV block), and renal (IgA nephropathy).

Key learning point: Ankylosing spondylitis commonly presents with chronic back pain and is frequently associated with acute anterior uveitis, leading to recurring eye redness and pain.
questions.hint: This young man, who presents with a C2 vertebral fracture following a fall, has a 2-year history of lower back pain of the inflammatory type (indicated by morning stiffness and worsening with rest), limited range of motion of the lumbar spine, and evidence of sacroiliitis on MRI. These findings suggest ankylosing spondylitis (AS), which may lead to osteoporosis and an increased risk of pathological fractures.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to your clinic for evaluation of worsening back pain. The pain started 10 months ago, is worse in the morning, and improves with activity. He also reports bilateral hip pain and difficulty bending forward during exercise for the past 3 months. He has a history of celiac disease and follows a gluten-free diet. On examination, there is a limited range of spinal flexion. Flexion, abduction, and external rotation of both hips elicit pain. Further evaluation is most likely to show which one of the following laboratory findings?

choices.text: Presence of anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are diagnostic of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Although this patient 's history of celiac disease (an autoimmune disease) and joint pain are associated with SLE, he has no other evidence of the disease (e.g., malar rash, photosensitivity).

B) INCORRECT:

HLA-DR3 is positive in some autoimmune diseases, including systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Although this patient 's history of celiac disease (an autoimmune disease) and joint pain are associated with SLE, this patient has no other evidence of the disease (e.g., malar rash, photosensitivity).

C) INCORRECT:

The presence of both anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies is suggestive of either Sjogren's syndrome or systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), for which this patient is at increased risk (history of Celiac disease). While both diseases frequently cause joint pain, this patient lacks associated symptoms (e.g., dry eye/mouth for Sjogren's syndrome or rash for SLE).

D) CORRECT:

90–95% of patients with ankylosing spondylitis are HLA-B27 positive, compared to 6% of the general population. HLA-B27 testing is indicated to diagnose ankylosing spondylitis in patients with an inconclusive clinical presentation and pelvic x-ray.

Although most patients with ankylosing spondylitis are HLA-B27 positive, fewer than 5% of people who are HLA-B27 positive develop the disease. Isolated HLA-B27 positivity has little clinical significance. Gene positivity only supports the diagnosis in patients with clinical suspicion of an associated disease (e.g., chronic lower back pain and morning stiffness).

Key learning point: Ankylosing spondylitis is strongly associated with HLA-B27 positivity, a genetic marker found in most affected individuals.

E) INCORRECT:

Although rheumatoid factor is a nonspecific finding, it is classically associated with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and absent in seronegative spondyloarthropathies. Unlike this patient, RA typically causes a symmetric polyarthritis (usually the PIP and MCP joints of the hands) in women of childbearing age and rarely affects the thoracic or lumbar spine.
questions.hint: This patient's history of progressively worsening back pain that is worse in the morning, impaired spinal flexion, and bilateral hip pain are consistent with ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 7-month history of increasing lower back and neck pain. He reports that the pain is worse in the morning and improves with activity, such as playing basketball. Over the past 2 months, he has also noticed shortness of breath during exercise. On examination, there is tenderness over the sacroiliac joints and range of motion is limited by pain. Chest expansion is decreased on full inspiration. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Laboratory studies show a white blood cell count of 14.0 × 109/L (3.5–10.5) and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 84 mm/h (0–10). X-ray of the spine reveals erosion and sclerosis of the sacroiliac joints and loss of spinal lordosis. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which one of the following?

choices.text: Tenderness at the Achilles tendon insertion site.
Hyperextension of the proximal interphalangeal joints with flexion of the distal interphalangeal joints.
Nail pitting and separation of the nail from the nailbed.
Erythema and inflammation of the conjunctiva.
Paresthesia over the anterolateral part of the thigh.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:
