Tenderness at the Achilles tendon insertion site indicates heel enthesitis, which is a common finding in individuals with AS. About half of the patients with AS will have enthesitis at some point in the course of the disease. Enthesitis is generally a clinical diagnosis, but ultrasonography can also be used for the detection and assessment of the condition.

Individuals with AS commonly develop restrictive pulmonary disease as a result of the decreased mobility of their spine and thorax. This is likely the cause of this patient's shortness of breath and decreased chest expansion on inspiration.

Key learning point: Ankylosing spondylitis commonly presents with enthesitis, such as tenderness at the Achilles tendon insertion, due to inflammation at sites where tendons or ligaments attach to bone.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperextension of the proximal interphalangeal joints with flexion of the distal interphalangeal joints is the swan neck deformity commonly seen in chronic established rheumatoid arthritis (RA). RA can also cause joint stiffness that improves with activity and lung disease. However, it more commonly affects middle-aged women and involves the peripheral small and large joints and the cervical spine, with very infrequent involvement of the thoracolumbar spine and sacroiliac joints.

C) INCORRECT:

Onycholysis (separation of the nail from the nail bed) and nail pitting commonly occur in individuals with psoriatic arthritis. Although a subtype of psoriatic arthritis can affect the spine, causing sacroiliitis and spondylitis, individuals are more likely to have dactylitis. Additionally, individuals typically have skin lesions typical of psoriasis. Lastly, the radiologic features of psoriatic arthritis commonly involve unilateral sacroiliitis with erosion and new bone formation, which is not seen on this patient's x-ray.

D) INCORRECT:

Erythema and inflammation of the conjunctiva (conjunctivitis) are seen in reactive arthritis. While individuals with reactive arthritis can present with lower back pain and sacroiliitis, asymmetrical oligoarthritis of the lower extremities is more typical. Additionally, this man does not have a history of a preceding bacterial infection of the gastrointestinal or genitourinary tract or other features of reactive arthritis, e.g., a lesion on the glans penis (balanitis circinata) or hyperkeratinization of the palms and soles (keratoma blenorrhagicum). This patient most likely has ankylosing spondylitis, which is associated with acute unilateral anterior uveitis (∼ 25% of cases).

E) INCORRECT:

Paresthesia and pain over the anterolateral part of the thigh is a common finding in individuals with spinal disk herniation at the L2–L3 level. While herniated disks can present with decreased range of motion of the spine, individuals typically have spinal tenderness at the affected site, in this case over the L2–L3 spinous processes. Additionally, individuals with L2–L3 disk herniation have weakness of their quadriceps and a diminished knee reflex. Spinal disk herniation does not cause reduced chest expansion, leukocytosis, or a raised ESR. Lastly, x-ray findings of disk herniation show decreased disk height without involvement of the sacroiliac joint.
questions.hint: Back pain that is worse in the morning and improves with physical activity, in combination with leukocytosis, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), and characteristic x-ray findings (erosion and sclerosis of the sacroiliac joints, loss of spinal lordosis), suggests ankylosing spondylitis (AS).

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of progressive swelling and restricted motion of his right third finger. He denies trauma, fever, or recent infection. He also reports several months of dull lower back pain that is worse in the morning and improves with activity, as well as intermittent pain at the back of his heels. Physical examination shows diffuse swelling of the right third finger and tenderness at the Achilles tendon insertions. No cutaneous or nail changes are present. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F). Laboratory studies show ESR 55 mm/hr. X-ray of the lower back shows bilateral sacroiliac joint margin irregularity and early sclerosis. Which of the following diagnoses best explains this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reactive arthritis typically follows a recent gastrointestinal or genitourinary infection and often includes urethritis, conjunctivitis, or mucocutaneous lesions. In the absence of a preceding infection or extra-articular features of that syndrome, this diagnosis is less likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Psoriatic arthritis can manifest with dactylitis and asymmetric peripheral joint involvement. However, it is usually associated with cutaneous psoriasis, scalp lesions, or nail pitting, and the absence of these findings makes this diagnosis less likely.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – Ankylosing spondylitis is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy that manifests with inflammatory back pain and sacroiliitis. Extraspinal manifestations such as dactylitis and enthesitis are also seen. Chronic morning stiffness improving with activity, bilateral sacroiliac joint changes, and elevated inflammatory markers are consistent with this condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis may manifest with hand joint pain and stiffness. However, RA typically causes symmetric involvement of the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints rather than uniform swelling of an entire digit.

E) INCORRECT:

Enteropathic arthritis can manifest with axial pain, enthesitis, and peripheral joint inflammation. However, it is associated with inflammatory bowel disease and is typically accompanied by gastrointestinal symptoms such as chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, or rectal bleeding. The absence of these features makes this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with ankylosing spondylitis presents to the emergency department with acute back pain after slipping and hitting his back on a table. He reports that the pain is different from his usual chronic discomfort. On examination, he has a fixed thoracic kyphosis and is unable to lie flat. Neurological examination shows intact motor function and sensation in all extremities. After establishing spinal precautions, what is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain plain radiographs of the thoracic and lumbar spine
Administer high-dose NSAIDs and reassess in 2 hours
Obtain CT imaging of the sacroiliac joints and spine
Perform MRI of the entire spine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Plain radiographs are inadequate for detecting fractures in patients with ankylosing spondylitis because they have kyphosis and secondary bone formation that can obscure fracture lines. Cross-sectional imaging is preferred as the initial modality.

B) INCORRECT:

While NSAIDs are first-line treatment for symptoms of chronic ankylosing spondylitis, new acute pain after even a minor trauma suggests a possible spinal fracture. Imaging should not be delayed for pain management in this high-risk scenario.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- CT imaging is the most appropriate initial step in management for suspected spinal fractures in patients with ankylosing spondylitis. Plain radiographs can miss fractures due to existing kyphosis and secondary bone formation, making CT the preferred initial study to detect chalk stick fractures.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with ankylosing spondylitis who develop new acute pain after trauma are at high risk for spinal fractures and require immediate evaluation. Discharge without imaging is inappropriate given the risk of unstable fractures and potential spinal cord injury.

E) INCORRECT:

While MRI provides excellent soft tissue detail and can detect fractures, CT is preferred for trauma evaluation in patients with ankylosing spondylitis. MRI may be considered if CT is inconclusive or if spinal cord injury is suspected.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the urgent care clinic because of low back pain and stiffness. The symptoms are worse upon waking and improve with exercise. He also reports intermittent chest pain with deep inspiration. Physical examination shows decreased lumbar spine flexion. Radiographs of the pelvis show bilateral sacroiliitis. Which of the following additional physical examination findings is most likely to be present in this patient?

choices.text: Erythematous rash over the cheeks and nasal bridge
Tenderness to palpation at the insertion of the Achilles tendon
Bony enlargement of the distal interphalangeal joints
Ulnar deviation of the metacarpophalangeal joints

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An erythematous rash over the cheeks and nasal bridge (malar or “butterfly” rash) is a characteristic finding in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Although SLE can cause arthritis, it is typically a non-erosive polyarthritis. The prominent sacroiliitis and inflammatory axial back pain seen in this patient are not typical features of SLE.

B) CORRECT:

AS primarily affects the axial skeleton. It is a type of spondyloarthropathy, a group of diseases characterized by enthesitis, which is inflammation at sites where tendons, ligaments, or joint capsules insert into bone. The Achilles tendon insertion at the calcaneus is one of the most common sites for enthesitis. Other common sites include the plantar fascia insertion and costochondral junctions, which can explain this patient's chest pain. The most common extraarticular manifestation of AS is acute anterior uveitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Bony enlargement of the distal interphalangeal joints, known as Heberden nodes, is a hallmark of osteoarthritis (OA). OA is a degenerative joint disease, and this patient's symptoms have an inflammatory pattern (worse with rest, better with activity), which is inconsistent with OA. Furthermore, OA does not typically cause sacroiliitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Ulnar deviation of the metacarpophalangeal joints is a classic deformity seen in advanced, erosive rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Although RA is an inflammatory arthritis, it typically manifests as a symmetric polyarthritis of the small joints of the hands and feet, and sacroiliitis is not a characteristic feature. This patient's axial-dominant symptoms are not typical of RA.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms of back pain, morning stiffness, reduced spinal mobility, as well as bilateral sacroillitis, raise suspicion for ankylosing spondylitis (AS).
